Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The temple holds a routine evening chant.
Story:
The snow fell in thick, blinding sheets as I gripped the steering wheel, my taxi crawling along the icy road. My passenger, a nervous businessman, kept glancing at his watch, voice tight with urgency. “Please, I can’t miss this flight. Is there any way you can go faster?” His words pressed on me, the expectation clear: get him to the airport, no matter the weather. But the roads were slick, and every turn felt like a test of my skill and luck. I wanted to help him, to be the reliable driver he needed.

Yet, as the clock ticked closer to six, my mind drifted to the temple. Tonight was the evening chant, a ritual I rarely missed. My teacher always said, “Our presence is our practice.” The community would notice my absence, and I felt the weight of their silent expectation. I was torn—between the duty to my passenger and the commitment to my sangha. The storm outside was nothing compared to the storm inside me, as I wrestled with which path to follow.
